patient_information: 67-year-old German woman, lived as expatriate in Cameroon for past 4 years, past medical history otherwise unremarkable.
chief_complaint: Palpitations, transient subcutaneous swellings for past year.
history_of_present_illness: Palpitations. Transient subcutaneous swellings for past year. No fever or constitutional symptoms. 24-hour ECG showed paroxysmal supraventricular extrasystoles. Echocardiography revealed minimal pericardial effusion.
exposure_and_epidemiology: Expatriate in Cameroon, endemic for loiasis.
physical_exam: No visible subcutaneous swellings. Heart sounds clear and regular, no murmurs. No pathological findings.
labs_and_diagnostics: WBC 6.20 x10^9/L, haemoglobin 13.8 g/dL, platelets 155 x10^9/L, neutrophils 45%, eosinophils 14% (absolute 0.868 x10^9/L), band neutrophils 1%, lymphocytes 36%, monocytes 4%, basophils 0%. Chest radiograph normal.
differential_diagnosis: Filarial infection key given transient swellings, eosinophilia, Cameroon residence. Non-specific urticaria, Calabar swellings in loiasis, cysticercosis, larva currens in strongyloidiasis, Mansonella perstans. Acute schistosomiasis but afebrile, no urticaria. Gnathostomiasis, sparganosis more East Asia but some in Africa.
management_and_clinical_course: Serology for filarial infections positive. Day-blood samples filtered and Giemsa stained revealed sheathed microfilariae with tapered tail characteristic for Loa loa, count 1400/mL. Treated with albendazole followed by ivermectin, tolerated well. Absolute eosinophil count returned to normal, microfilarial count declined. Palpitations settled. Follow-up echocardiography normal, pericardial effusion resolved, 24-hour ECG normal.
final_diagnosis: Loiasis caused by Loa loa, confirmed by microscopy showing characteristic microfilariae. Diagnosis aligns with transient swellings, eosinophilia, cardiac arrhythmia, endemic area. Alternatives ruled out by confirmatory microscopy.
